video.title: OpenCV Course - Full Tutorial with Python
video.description:
Learn everything you need to know about OpenCV in this full course for beginners. You will learn the very basics (reading images and videos, image transformations) to more advanced concepts (color spaces, edge detection). Towards the end, you'll have hands-on experience building a Deep Computer Vision model to classify between the characters in the popular TV series "The Simpsons".

⭐️ Code ⭐️
🔗Github link: https://github.com/jasmcaus/opencv-course
🔗The Caer Vision library: https://github.com/jasmcaus/caer

🎥 Course from Jason Dsouza: 
- Check out his Youtube channel: https://www.youtube.com/jasmcaus 
- Follow him on Twitter: https://twitter.com/jasmcaus

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:07) Installing OpenCV and Caer
Section #1 - Basics
⌨️ (0:04:12) Reading Images & Video
⌨️ (0:12:57) Resizing and Rescaling Frames
⌨️ (0:20:21) Drawing Shapes & Putting Text
⌨️ (0:31:55) 5 Essential Functions in OpenCV
⌨️ (0:44:13) Image Transformations
⌨️ (0:57:06) Contour Detection
Section #2 - Advanced
⌨️ (1:12:53) Color Spaces
⌨️ (1:23:10) Color Channels
⌨️ (1:31:03) Blurring
⌨️ (1:44:27) BITWISE operations
⌨️ (1:53:06) Masking
⌨️ (2:01:43) Histogram Computation
⌨️ (2:15:22) Thresholding/Binarizing Images
⌨️ (2:26:27) Edge Detection
Section #3 - Faces:
⌨️ (2:35:25) Face Detection with Haar Cascades
⌨️ (2:49:05) Face Recognition with OpenCV's built-in recognizer
Section #4 - Capstone
⌨️ (3:11:57) Deep Computer Vision: The Simpsons

⭐️ More ways to connect with Jason Dsouza ⭐️
- Medium: https://jasmcaus.medium.com
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/jasmcaus
- LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/jasmcaus

✏️ Check out Jason's Deep Learning Crash Course for Beginners: https://youtu.be/VyWAvY2CF9c

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

The error in the face recognizer is due to 3:04:44
It should be 
for (x, y, w, h) in face_rects:

instead of:
for (x, y, w, h) in face_rects:
    faces_roi = gray[y:y+h, x:x+h]

replies.author: The Companion Cube
replies.text: In numpy array dimension [0] means row (vertical dimension) and [1] means column (Horizontal dimension). But in image, width is horizontal, and height is vertical. that's why it's flipped. try to draw a 9 pixel array on a paper to visualize it yourself

topLevelComment.author: Tester Pokemon
topLevelComment.text: Thank you so much! One question: Do I need to "normalise" the input image before send it into model.prediction in the Simpsons demo?

replies.author: Jason Dsouza
replies.text: Depends what you mean by normalise. To train effectively, your input images will need to be structurally similar - this means that if one input image is 640x320, *all* the other images must be 640x320. If you expose one image to mean subtraction, it would be wise to do the same for the rest of the images. Hope this helps! Cheers :)

topLevelComment.text: 2:08:26 — actually everything was OK. You don't need to pass masked image to calcHist mask parameter. You can just pass white circle instead, as you did first time. It worked because cats-in-a-circle image is identical to white circle in bitwise operations (if those cats have no zero valued pixels in the circle region)

replies.author: 193 51 Shon
replies.text: you will get a grayscale image because merge function looks for matrices in the order [b,g,r] the reason you get red when you pass [blank, blank, r] is because you are telling the values of [b, g] = 0 and show me only red when you pass [r, r, r] you say all [b, g, r] = r so it shows a grayscale image which indicates the intensity of distribution of red pixel(s).

topLevelComment.author: Favour Okia

replies.author: hammadharoon
replies.text:
i had the same issue, i googled what a confidence of 0 meant, and some sources said it means its 'fully confident'. in any case it isn't ideal, nor is it realistic for a prediction to be fully confident. It turned out that i used the same image that i trained, to test the model. so if you look carefully, the folder that he gets the test image from is a different folder than the ones he got the training image from (folder called val, for validation).

you have to choose a different image than the ones you used for training, and you'll get a different confidence level than 0.

the circle is a blank image with a white circle inside.
the mask is also an image but you are filling the cirlce with the cropped image.
using cv.calcHisto() if you pass circle or mask, it will take it then use it as a mask, ignoring the blank area, whether the mask region(circle) was filled with white or with a cropped image.
